tn.text: These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
The words "their hearts" refer to the whole person. AT: "they" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The words "their lips" refer to the whole person. AT: "they" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"talk about causing harm" or "talk about creating problems"
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).

tn.ref: Through wisdom a house is built
tn.text: The abstract noun "wisdom" can be translated as an adjective. These words can be translated in active form. AT: "People need to be wise if they are to build a good house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The abstract noun "understanding" can be translated as a verb. These words can be translated in active form. AT: "People need to understand what is morally good and what is morally bad if they are to establish a house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

made stable and strong. The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, and the house being physically stable and strong is a metaphor for a family that lives in peace. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: By knowledge the rooms are filled
tn.text: The abstract noun "knowledge" can be translated as a verb. These words can be translated in active form. AT: "People need to know what is precious and pleasant if they are to fill their rooms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
The abstract noun "wisdom" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "wise warrior" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: a man of knowledge increases his strength
tn.text: The abstract nouns "knowledge" and "strength" can be translated as the verb "know" and the adjective "strong." AT: "a man who knows many things is stronger because he knows these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "direction" can be translated as a verb. AT: "if you have wise people telling you what to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"fight"
those who tell government officials what those officials should do
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
This is an idiom. "too difficult for a fool to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The mouth is a metonym for the words that come from the mouth. AT: "speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
one who is skillful at making evil plans. AT: "a mischievous person" or "a troublemaker"
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
This is an idiom. AT: "you have very little strength" or "you are certainly weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).

tn.ref: those who are being taken away
tn.text: These words can be translated in active form. AT: "those whom they are taking away," where "they" could be anyone, but are probably government officials. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Another possible meaning is "dragged away."
walking unsteadily and almost falling. This word would also describe the way a person walks when he is being dragged away.

The abstract noun "slaughter" can be translated as a verb. The writer speaks as if those who take them away think of them as no better than animals. If your language has a word for killing animals that would fit here, you might want to use it. AT: "where people will kill them as they would kill animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer is answering something that the reader may wrongly be thinking. AT: "You may say, 'Behold, ... this,' but does"
"Listen to us! We" or "But we" or "We have done nothing wrong, because we"

tn.ref: does not the one who weighs the heart understand what you are saying?
tn.text: The writer assumes the readers know the answer and asks this for emphasis. AT: "the one who weighs the heart understands what you are saying." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The writer expects the reader to know that "the one" is Yahweh. AT: "Yahweh, who" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

The word "heart" is a metonym for what a person thinks and desires. The writer speaks as if what a person thinks and desires were a physical object that a person could weigh, and weighing an object is a metaphor for looking closely at something to see how good it is. AT: "knows how good what people really think and desire is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The one who guards your life, does he not know it?
tn.text: The writer assumes the readers know the answer and asks this for emphasis. AT: "The one who guards your life knows it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Will God not give to each one what he deserves?
tn.text: The writer assumes the readers know the answer and asks this for emphasis. AT: "God will give to each one what he deserves." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).

tn.ref: your hope will not be cut off
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) this is a simple passive that can be translated as in active form. AT: "no one will take your hope away" or 2) this is litotes that can be translated in positive form. AT: "your hope will surely continue" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
The words "lie in wait" are an idiom. AT: "Do not hide and wait for the right time." Translate "lie in wait" as in [[:en:bible:notes:pro:01:10|1:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
the home of the righteous person
"gets back on his feet" or "stands up"

tn.ref: wicked people are brought down by calamity
tn.text: The writer speaks as if "calamity" were a person who could do bad things to other people. These words can be translated in active form. AT: "God will use calamity to bring down the wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a metaphor of a person who was standing but someone has brought him down to the ground or made him fall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
times when bad things happen to people and their property
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
"something bad happens to your enemy"

tn.ref: let not your heart be glad
tn.text: This is a strong command. The word "heart" is a metonym for the person. AT: "do not allow yourself to be glad" or "stop yourself from being glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: turn away his wrath from him
tn.text: The words "turn away his wrath" are an idiom for no longer being angry. What Yahweh would do instead can be made explicit. AT: "stop being angry with him and be angry with you instead" (see UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).

tn.ref: the lamp of wicked people will go out
tn.text: The lamp is used as a metaphor for life. The life of wicked people will end just as a lamp goes out. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These verses continue the "thirty sayings" ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:22:20|22:20]]).
a deep respect and awe for a person in authority

tn.ref: who knows the extent of the destruction that will come from both of them?
tn.text: The writer asks this question to emphasize the disaster. AT: "no one knows the extent of the destruction that will come from both of them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
these words refer to Yahweh and the king

tn.ref: These also are sayings of the wise
tn.text: This sentence starts a new collection of proverbs.
a situation that is brought before a judge in which someone is accused of breaking the law

tn.ref: Whoever says to the wicked person, ... will be cursed by peoples and hated by nations
tn.text: The word "nations" is a metonym for the people who live in the nations. These words can be translated in active form. AT: "People will curse whoever says to the wicked person, ... , and the people of other nations will hate him"

tn.ref: the wicked person ... a righteous person
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) people should never call any wicked person a righteous person or 2) no one should say of a person guilty of a crime that he is innocent. AT: "a person guilty of a crime ... innocent"
"will be very happy"

tn.ref: gifts of goodness will come to them
tn.text: Gifts are spoken of as if they were people who could move by themselves. The abstract noun "goodness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "people will give them good gifts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and[[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"good things" or "blessings"

tn.ref: gives a kiss on the lips
tn.text: A kiss was a sign of respect and devotion in that culture. AT: "shows true friendship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The lips are a metonym for the words a person speaks. AT: "by what you say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom.  "take revenge against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
useless plants with sharp spines
plants that are covered with stinging leaves and hairs
"had fallen down"
"learned a lesson"

tn.ref: A little sleep ... to rest—and poverty comes
tn.text: You may need to fill in the omitted words. AT: "You may say to yourself, 'A little sleep ... to rest'—but then poverty will come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

Some translations read, "poverty comes upon you like a robber." Poverty is spoken of as if it were a person or animal that can attack a lazy person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: your needs like an armed soldier
tn.text: Needs are spoken of as if they were a person who could attack the lazy person. AT: "your needs will come to you like an armed soldier" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
